subtopic: DEBT SERVICING AND ACCOUNT REDUCTION ACT

speechtext: The House proceeded to the consideration of Bill C-21, an act relating to the accounting of certain payments for the servicing and reduction of the debt of Canada, as reported (with amendments) from the Standing Committee on Finance.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
There are six motions in amendment at report stage to Bill C-21.

Motion No. 1, standing in the name of the hon. member for Essex-Windsor, and Motion No. 2, standing in the name of the hon. member for Kamloops, are identical. After consultation, I chose Motion No. 2 to be debated and voted on separately.

Motion No. 3, standing in the name of the hon. member for Essex-Windsor, and Motion No. 4, standing in the name of the hon. member for Kamloops, are identical. Motion No. 5, standing in the name of the hon. member for Essex-Windsor, and Motion No. 6, standing in the name of the hon. member for Kamloops, are also identical. After consultation, I have selected Motions Nos. 4 and 6 for debate. They will be grouped for debate, with a vote on Motion No. 4 applying to Motion No. 6.

I will now submit Motion No. 2 to the House.

Motion No. 2
That Bill C-21 be amended in Clause 4 by striking out lines 22
and 23 at page 1 and lines 1 to 20 at page 2.
He said: Madam Speaker, I certainly want to say first of all that your decision on the appropriate way to proceed this morning has been first rate.
I would like to explain there might seem to have been some duplication between my hon. friend from Essex- Windsor and myself. The reality is that the hon. member for Essex-Windsor is busy today pursuing duties outside the House. As a result he is unable to be here.
He was hoping to be here, so that is the reason for what appears to be duplication. It is not duplication. The fact is that I am pinch-hitting for my hon. friend. I appreciate the support that my friends from the Official Opposition give as well.
I want to begin my discussion in the debate on Motion No. 2 by identifying first what became clear in committee. That is, this bill is essentially a phoney bill.
The bill is an effort by the government to justify the goods and services tax by suggesting that the surplus revenues raised by the goods and services tax would be used to reduce the deficit and pay down the debt and therefore, the structuring of this special accounting procedure.
All it is is a bit of smoke and mirrors in an effort to say that this goods and services tax is good for Canada because it will be used to pay down the deficit. That is absolute nonsense. If the government was interested in paying down the deficit, it is simply a matter of having excess funds at the end of the year depending on various programs, and that would occur naturally.
There is no need for a special account or special legislation. It is simply a matter of good government. Since we do not have good government, obviously the government has had to come up with some type of

March 27, 1992
Government Orders
imagery to give the impression at least, that it is attempting to do this.
I say that as sort of a preliminary statement. Anybody who is taking this as a serious initiative by the government obviously does not recognize the pure politics of this. I feel very saddened that politics has had to become involved in this critical issue in terms of deficit and debt reduction. Once again, that is the government's decision.
What this amendment does is it says that in the legislation generally, it identifies the GST surpluses to be used to reduce the deficit and pay down the debt. It also includes the possible sale of select Crown corporations, the proceeds of which would be used again to reduce the deficit or pay down the debt.
What has become clear when looking at the reaction that various witnesses have provided is that this provides the government with an opportunity to hold some fire sales and start selling off, if you like, government assets.
They've been doing that already.

My hon. friend from Kingston and the Islands reminds me, unfortunately, that they have already started to do this in some rather illogical ways.
Setting that aside, what this will do is provide the government with the incentive to hold a fire sale and sell off valuable government assets to, at the last minute, probably before an election, pay down the deficit, or at least to give this impression.
In the best interests of the country, Canadians have said that this is not the appropriate course of action and that Canadians do not support this course of action. It would simply not be a logical clause to have continue with the legislation.
My hon. colleague from Essex-Windsor, and now through my own motion, simply says: "Let us eliminate from the legislation, that particular sector". Anybody who has studied this with any detail would support this initiative.
I know my hon. friend across the way has indicated some interest in this provision. We are simply saying with this motion: "Let us remove the lines at the bottom of page 1 and the first 20 lines on the top of page 2". That would essentially eliminate the Crown corporations from being part of this phoney deficit reduction legislation.
It is as straightforward as that. If we would simply adopt this motion, we could proceed then and deal quickly with the remainder.

speakeroldname: Mr. Pierre H. Vincent (Parliamentary Secretary to Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, we are considering Bill C-21, an Act relating to the accounting of certain payments for the servicing and reduction of the debt of Canada.
This government announced a wonderful measure to create through legislation a fund where all the net revenue from the GST, sales of companies, privatization and money that some Canadians want to give to the government would go for the sole purpose of reducing our national debt and/or our interest payments on it.
My colleague opposite says that we should take out the money from any sale of companies that the government owns, i.e. privatization, to see what we get from the GST. Madam Speaker, I think it is completely frivolous to want what Canadians do not want. Why have only the amount collected from the GST, when the books for the fund to be created will be audited annually by the Canadian government's accountant, so that we will be able to identify very clearly the net receipts from the GST. We will also be able to identify very clearly the net receipts from the privatization of companies and also identify the amounts received from Canadians.
I should tell the hon. member that in 10 months, the Canadian government has already received $375,000 from some Canadian taxpayers and this money was used to pay the interest on the debt and thus lower the tax burden. It is important to point out that so far $375,000 has been received from Canadian taxpayers in addition to the income taxes that they have to pay. Madam Speaker, that shows how important Canadians consider this bill to be and how important it is for them to have a fund where the money needed to pay the interest on our debts and eventually pay them off can go.
Madam Speaker, you will remember as I do that when we were elected in 1984, we talked about the countless Crown corporations, most of which operated at a loss, and we all knew that they were competing with private enterprise. In 1984, Canadians gave us a clear mandate
March 27, 1992

Government Orders
to get rid of companies that cost us money and competed with private enterprise.
In 1988, Madam Speaker, in the riding of Trois-Ri-vieres, I listed the companies that had been sold or privatized and said that we would continue to do so. The riding of Trois-Rivieres gave a clear mandate to your humble servant and the Conservative Party to continue to get rid of the lame ducks which the previous government had bought or set up and so on.
What we are saying today is that the money from the sale of companies, that is the net proceeds, in addition to GST revenue, will be used to reduce the interest payable on the debt and eventually to reduce the debt itself.
The only justification for the NDP motion, Madam Speaker, is allegedly to avoid any possible fire sales. This government to date has privatized companies remarkably well. It has managed to get some Crown corporations back on track and sell them at a profit. The object of the exercise is to dispose of them, but at the same time make money and/or stop losing it. Do not forget that every time the government puts money in a company it owns that competes with the private sector, Canadians' taxes are being used to give a Crown corporation money to compete with other companies that do not have public funds. That is completely illogical, Madam Speaker.
Whence the importance of privatizing companies, and because we have a deficit and a national debt, it is also important to take this money to reduce the interest on the debt and/or the debt itself. Even if we removed the proceeds of privatization from this fund, the government could still sell the companies. Every time it sells a company, it is done publicly and advertised and can be audited by any accountant or lawyer in the country. So my colleague's suggestion of not including privatization proceeds in the fund because it might lead to fire sales makes no sense at all.
Madam Speaker, I hope that this House will reject this motion as quickly as possible so that this bill as presented can pass third reading in the shortest time, especially since that is what Canadians want.

Madam Speaker, it is very appropriate today that I support the motion from the House leader of the New Democratic Party. I support it because this government has a track record of dismantling just about every federal national institution that exists in this country. So often we have seen that the process or the management of the dissolution or the dismantling has really not been in the best interests of Canadian taxpayers.
Just think of the Air Canada transaction where it went to the market and dumped the first portion of shares. Independent analysts said that it was dumping those shares at approximately $2 below share value. That is not the right way to go.
What did it do with the proceeds of the shares on Air Canada? It did not take the proceeds and put them back into the federal treasury. It took the proceeds of the shares on the sale of Air Canada and put them into that portion of the corporation that had been privatized. This was almost like a double-dip for the person who had acquired the shares. There was absolutely no public accountability and no debate on that particular transaction.
Before Christmas we passed a bill in this House which essentially allowed the sale of Crown lands by just choosing three independent people to do an appraisal. Once you get those three independent appraisals, the government by Order in Council is allowed to make the transaction. In other words it does not have to come to Parliament.
This Government of Canada has on its balance sheet billions and billions of dollars in assets. They could be in land, buildings, airports, harbours or Crown corporations. Under that bill which we passed before Christmas there is no accountability on the disposition of those lands.
We have a depressed market in our country right now. Let us take, for example, my part of the country. We have tens of thousands of acres in Pickering that we assembled for the super airport that we should have but never did build. It was our government that did not build it, but we made a mistake I believe. There are thousands and thousands of acres there for sale as of the last

March 27, 1992
Government Orders
budget. We just have to read the newspaper today to see what is happening to the Reichmanns. Olympia & York real estate right now is in the gutter, it is so depressed, it is so low. Therefore, the value of those Crown lands at this moment are very low.
Technically, Public Works Canada could get three independent appraisals on the value of the lands. People could put in bids. They would all be low. Even if they took the highest bid, because the market is depressed, it would literally be a giveaway. Two years, three years from now we may need that land not only for a possible airport, we may need it to lever the province for housing or some other project. I do not know. We will kick ourselves because we gave the government the power to basically get rid of it, sell it off, all in the name of debt reduction.
I always use the example of the House of Commons. Technically speaking, with the act that we passed before Christmas combined with this bill, this government has the power by Order in Council to take bids on this Crown land, this House of Commons. Technically speaking, it could sell it without any debate on the floor of this House. That is a fact, all in the name of debt reduction.
That is not a bad idea.

The hon. member said that it is not a bad idea. I am sure most Canadians would probably agree with him most days, that it is not a bad idea.
The member for the New Democratic Party in putting forward this motion is trying in a genuine way to put the brakes on this presidential style government where it can just do everything by Order in Council, where there is no debate, no discussion on the floor of the House of Commons.
I gave the example before of the federal presence lands, the Crown lands, Crown buildings in the province of Quebec. We have billions and billions of dollars of Crown lands in the province of Quebec. Let us imagine after the next election the possibility of a pequiste government. Let us imagine that Mr. Parizeau-it is not impossible-could be the premier. Let us imagine he said to his minister of finance: "Let's go and buy off all the federal lands in the province of Quebec". The cabinet here might say: "Listen, in the name of debt reduction, in the name of deficit reduction, let's do a deal with this minister of finance". It is technically possible.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance
speechtext: There is no money.
What do you mean, no money?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance
speechtext: Quebec won't have any money.

What do you mean Quebec will not have any money? It does not need any money. All it needs is paper, an IOU. It is no different than the deal that we made with terminal 3. It is no different than the deal that Bobby Rae is trying with the dome stadium in Toronto. Here is a $700 million dome stadium and what is he doing? He is trying to sell it. I think we have actually caused them to rethink it because we have talked about it in this House a few times.
What the private sector says is: "Listen, premier of Ontario, we will buy this $700 million dome stadium. We will give you $100 million now and we will take a $225 million debenture, which we will not start paying the interest on until 20 years from now". Each of the 10 partners put in $10 million for the down payment. They borrowed that $10 million from the bank which means that it is only interest on $10 million. It is only costing them in cash $1 million each to get the $100 million and with the $100 million they have a $700 million deal. Mr. Parizeau, and I say this with respect to some of my business colleagues in Toronto, is just as smart as those guys. I can tell you right now, if he could see an opportunity to cherry pick, buy off the federal lands, the Crown lands in the province of Quebec, under this bill, it could happen by Order in Council without any public debate in this Chamber. I do not think that is right. In fact, if I had my way around here right now, I would be reinforcing the federal presence, not just in the province of Quebec, but in every part of this country.
Madam Speaker, I see you giving me the signal to wrap it up. It is not too often that I agree with the NDP, but on this particular motion I believe they are right on track and I give it my full support.

Madam Speaker, I rise in support of the motion, the deletion basically that my colleague from Kamloops moved and I seconded.
At the outset, I want to read into the record that clause because people who are watching and people who read Hansard need to know the specifics of what we are talking. The area to be deleted is clause 4, subclauses (b) and (c) which read as follows:
March 27, 1992

(b)	the amount, if any, by which any amount received as consideration for the sale of shares in the capital stock of a Crown corporation or of a corporation that was previously a Crown corporation or that is a successor to a Crown corporation exceeds the value of the shares as shown in the accounts of Canada immediately before the time of the sale;
(c)	the amount, if any, by which any amount received on the winding up of a particular Crown corporation or of a particular corporation that was previously a Crown corporation or a successor to a Crown corporation exceeds the value of the shares of, or the interest of the government in, the particular Crown corporation or of the particular corporation, as the case may be, as shown in the accounts of Canada at the end of the last fiscal year of the government before the commencement of the winding up; or
Now we understand them.

I want to touch on two specific aspects. Let us look at the sale of CN Explorations. It is a Crown corporation that is part of CN Rail. That Crown corporation has some annual revenue that goes to CN, the parent Crown corporation. As we know, CN, like CP, is not in the best financial shape. It is no different than the airlines. It is haemorrhaging. We have seen that in the thousands of jobs that have been cut. We have seen it in the thousands of miles of tracks that have been ripped up.
If this bill passes with this clause included in it, it means that when CN Route is sold, it does not get the money to help it to survive. The money is siphoned off to this phoney debt reduction or deficit reduction plan and there is no benefit. Quite frankly, if CN does not get the use of either the ongoing revenue from CN Explorations or the benefit of the capital from its sale, we are going to have to pay elsewhere. We are going to have to pay in terms of more job losses. We know that CN Rail is in a process of restructuring. I am sure it has kept Ron Lawless on for another three months so he can finish the dastardly deeds he started years ago in terms of the downsizing. We will pay in terms of higher rates, or the taxpayer will pay in terms of additional funds from the treasury that go to sustain the ongoing operations of CN Rail.
This clause has got to go. As phoney as the bill itself is, this clause makes it even worse.
Which clause?

I am dealing with clause 4 and the deletion of subclauses (b) and (c). Let me take us back to the sell-off of Air Canada, Canada's flagship in the air. The
Government Orders
government sold 100 per cent of its shares. If this bill with this particular clause had been in place then, that revenue would have gone for deficit reduction as opposed to where it should have gone, which is to increase safety for the airlines. The Government of Canada has had 70 vacancies in aircraft inspectors for several years, 70 inspectors short of what there should be. In the future this kind of sell-off would prevent the reallocation of resources, the reallocation of the capital gained by the sale of a Crown corporation back into that same industry.
It is not clear from my wording of this whether or not any of the funds that will be gained, and I use that term loosely, from the privatization of terminals 1 and 2 in Toronto, the most profitable airport in our system, will be used by Transport Canada again for improvements in the system.
We already know that the revenue to the federal treasury which will result from this privatization will be considerably less than the revenue the treasury gets today from the profits of Pearson airport. We know it will be less. It is just basic economics, I suggest. If we have a profit centre then part of that revenue goes to pay for that profit centre as opposed to being total profit coming to the federal treasury.
I support my colleague's amendment. I think it makes eminent sense. However, as I said before, the whole bill is dumb, phoney and misleading. It is not going to work in any case.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I would also like to contribute a few comments to the debate this morning on the report stage of Bill C-21.
I have been listening to the debate since we started at ten o'clock, and it is my impression that the government is acting after the fact, like the bank that left the door open and then decided to take all kinds of security measures after its safe was cracked during the night.
Earlier, I heard the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance talk about privatization and how the government sold a number of Crown corporations. I already made it clear during the debate on second reading that I did not agree with the bill as a whole. I think that if the government wants to reduce the debt, it

March 27, 1992
Government Orders
should introduce an accounting system that makes sense, which is what the rest of the country wants.
Through our Income Tax Act, we tell our business people how to keep their accounts and report their assets and liabilities, but the government still uses a cash accounting system. I think that is the problem. However, to get back to Crown corporations, Madam Speaker, during the past seven and a half years this government has either sold or privatized all Crown corporations that were crucial to the survival of this country.
They gave them away.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Yes, they gave them away, as the hon. member for Toronto said. It was a fire sale, and not just the ones that were losing money, but Crown corporations that were making a profit.
Because it is their philosophy to leave everything up to the private sector and let the market decide what happens to this country, they privatized practically everything. And now they say: If anything is sold, we have to do it according to the rules and put the money in a special debt reduction fund. Again, this is like the bank with its security measures after the fact. It is all a bit late in the game. That is what they are doing with this bill, and that is why I am against this motion. And not only should clause 4 be deleted, the whole bill should be dropped.
We had a report from the Auditor General who wanted to clean up the government's finances and even suggested standardized financial statements that would be accessible to all Canadians, so they could see the government's accounting activities for themselves. They are now operating on a cash accounting basis. And what is the government trying to do with this bill? It would have Canadians believe it is tidying up its finances, and that surplus moneys from the GST and sales of Crown corporations will all go straight into the debt reduction account. Madam Speaker, that is a lot of smoke and mirrors. In fact, it does not mean a thing. A government that tells Canadians that it wants to reduce the national debt while it is doing the exact opposite should not be surprised that today, Canadians no longer trust their political leaders.

Madam Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to make some very brief submissions on Bill C-21.1 did not intend to speak, but when I listened to my friend and colleague from Broadview-Greenwood and my friend and colleague from Montreal I felt compelled to make a few comments about Bill C-21.
As other members have indicated, this is a fraudulent, if I could use the term, piece of legislation. It does not mean anything. It is an attempt by the government to hoodwink Canadians into believing that something serious is being done about the national debt which stands at about $410 billion.
What it has done is bring forward Bill C-21. It is four or five pages long. There are eight sections to it. In effect it has brought in an act of Parliament to open up an account. This is like any individual home owner in the country deciding to open up a special bank account to deal solely with the mortgage on the house and once the interest is paid off to use the account to pay down the debt. Does that mean that the mortgage will be paid off any quicker? Does it mean that fewer interest payments will be made just because a separate account has been opened to pay for the mortgage? Somehow money has to go into this account in order to service the debt on the mortgage, to make the interest payments.
The government is saying that it will set up this special mortgage account to help pay off the interest on the debt over a long period of time. If it keeps its fingers crossed, once the deficit is eliminated it will be able to use the surplus to help pay off this huge national debt. Once it has eliminated the deficit it is going to have either a balanced budget or a surplus.
I can use the analogy of a homeowner with a mortgage account again. If he sells a car or some furniture, he can take that money and put it in the mortgage account to help make the monthly mortgage payment or to help reduce the mortgage on the house.
It is all smoke and mirrors. It may look tidy because a separate statement might come in at the end of every month and at the end of the year the bank may send something saying that x number of payments have been made on the mortgage debt. But ultimately there is only one income coming in and all the expenses to be met. The home owner is really not any further ahead by
March 27, 1992

setting up a special mortgage account. It does not do anything.
What is the net result of wasting our time here this morning and wasting everyone's time setting up a different bank account? Perhaps I am missing something and a government member could stand up to clarify it. Is there any real advantage to this bill being passed? Are we going to accelerate our mortgage payments on the national debt? Are we somehow going to get a better deal from the banks and pay less interest? What does it do? It does not do anything. It sets up another bureaucracy. It helps the Poindexters who push paper around to have a little extra work to do.
The reason I object to this nonsense is that Canadians want this place to be relevant. When they see the Parliament of Canada debating a stupid bill, Bill C-21, it makes them wonder. It makes thinking Canadians wonder about the priorities of this Parliament.
We have 1.5 million Canadians who are unemployed. We have over 2 million Canadians on welfare. We have people suffering out there because of the economic crisis. Instead of debating creative ways of putting people back to work and getting this country working again, instead of talking about what is of real concern to Canadians, we are debating setting up another bank account.
The government is setting us up for the next election. It is going to say to Canadians that it brought in the GST but it is not spending the GST on silly little things; it is taking all the revenues from the GST and from the sale of Crown assets and using that money to pay off the national debt.
A debt is a debt is a debt. Whether it is one account, 50 accounts or 150 accounts, the debt still has to be paid. The government wants Canadians to believe that somehow we are that much further ahead because these moneys will be used to pay off the debt.
We have heard the old adage about selling family assets to pay the rent, selling the furniture to pay the rent or to pay the mortgage. Let us think of the stupidity of that. If we keep selling the furniture to pay the rent, sooner or later all the furniture is going to be gone, but the rental payment has to be made at the beginning of the month. And sooner or later the sheriff is going to come knocking on the door.
Government Orders
The government is not kidding anybody by passing this special piece of legislation so that whenever it sells a Crown asset it will help pay the interest payment on the debt. As a country we have a limited amount of Crown assets of Crown corporations. If the government keeps selling federally owned lands, sooner or later it is all gone. It is history. There is no accountability as my friend from Broadview-Greenwood says. That is of major concern to people on this side of the House. There has to be some accountability.
We do not want cabinet ministers behind closed doors up a couple of floors from where we are speaking making decisions to sell off assets that belong to each and every Canadian without having some degree of accountability in this House.
If the government wants to sell the furniture to pay the rent then we, as the tenants or homeowners, at least should have the right to know what furniture is being sold off and on what conditions. That should be discussed in the family, not in a closet upstairs.
This place is where the government is held accountable. This place is where the government should come forward to explain its actions, not in some back room a few floors away from this Chamber.
In closing, let me just repeat what a waste of time it is, what misplaced priorities this government is demonstrating by bringing forward this phoney and fraudulent piece of legislation. Canadians out there are demanding that this Parliament become relevant and do something important, that it deal with the real issues and the real problems facing Canadians, but we are wasting our time discussing and debating setting up another bank account.

Madam Speaker, I completely agree with what my colleagues have said about this matter. We are speaking to the motions by the member for Kamloops.
The bill reminds me of a ceremony that was held to honour a local business person. The speakers said that he had made a lot of money in the flower business and so on, and talked about what a great fellow he was.
After all of the speeches were given he got up to speak for himself. He said that as a matter of fact he was not in flowers. He was in fertilizer. He did not make money in

Government Orders
flowers, actually he lost money. Finally, he was not involved in fertilizers, his brother was. That is a joke.
The bill is what we are talking about. I thought that joke was quite relevant. I left British Columbia out of the story. I was going to place the joke in B.C. but I decided not to in deference to my friends from B.C. They still did not laugh.
We have an enormous financial problem in Canada, brought on in very large measure by the government opposite. As has been pointed out, the former Minister of Finance, the member for Etobicoke Centre, added more red ink, more debt to the backs of young people, old people and middle-aged people than any other finance minister in Canadian history.
Government members run around the country telling anybody who will listen to them, which is increasingly not very many, that they are the paragons of fiscal virtue. I think that the debt was $168 billion when they came into office in 1984. It is now rapidly going over $420 billion. By the way, much of it is held outside of Canada.
When the Germans, the Japanese and the Taiwanese get tired of buying this government's debt paper, and to be fair the papers of the provinces and the private sector, if that day ever comes we will have an enormous problem in this country.
Our children are going to have an even greater problem because of the financial profligacy of this government and other governments-I concede that-over many, many years.
The government is introducing Bill C-21 and pretending to Canadians that it is actually going to use the GST funds to reduce the debt. When we bear in mind that there will be a deficit of at least $20 billion in the account for the next five years, how can any serious, intelligent person take the government seriously?
How can we ask Canadians to believe in this kind of measure?
There is the old statement that nobody ever went broke in Canada. Actually, it was an American story. I will put it in British Columbia.
There is the old story that nobody ever went broke in the United States underestimating the intelligence of the American people. I would put it to those opposite that this kind of bill will just increase the
cynicism across Canada. It will tell everybody who has passed their grade 9 examinations and who has ever looked at an economics book, and I submit that virtually no one on that side of the House has ever studied economics, that this is a complete farce.
This is the debt servicing and reduction account act. Is there one member on the other side who actually believes that this is actually anything other than smoke and mirrors? I would ask them to raise their hand. Not a single hand goes up. Those members do not even believe in it themselves.
They do not know over there whether they are Keynesians or Milton Friedman economists. I would bet that if we asked one of them if they could tell the difference between John Maynard Keynes and Milton Friedman they would have great difficulty in telling us the difference between their economic theories.
Keynesian economists argue that government must spend generously to kick-start stalled economies in times of difficulty. However, among weak-willed politicians the second half of Keynes' advice is virtually never followed. He said that we must save money in good times, which we had up until about a year and a half ago.
This country has completed six years of prosperity. However, the Mulroney government has run six years of large deficits totalling about $210 billion. It tells us that it is because compound interest only began in 1984, it did not exist before then.
Today this government has neither a sound fiscal policy nor even much ability to borrow money from people who have managed their economies more soundly in other parts of the world.
The monetarists say that inflation can be avoided if central banks will ensure that the money in an economy increases at the same rate as real growth in that economy. Specifically, central bank governors, like John Crow, must carefully control the amount of currency, bank deposits and other money instruments to ensure that the supply does not expand excessively and thereby cause prices to rise.
I will readily concede that Mr. Crow has done a great deal to bring inflation down. As we have heard many times, inflation is at an all-time low point. But at what price? How many of those in the constituency of Red Deer are unemployed today? In Edmonton the rate is more than 12 per cent. I think 40,000 or 50,000

Edmontonians are out of work. They do not want to be out of work.
At what point do we take the monetarist philosophy-Mr. Crow is certainly the best-known practitioner of it in this country-and say that at some point we have to ease up, we must circulate more currency, more purchasing power, more M-l and more M-2in the economy?
This bill is simply part of an effort by those opposite to convince Canadians that they are doing something when the only thing they are doing is trying to grind the economy into cement. If they do not realize that then they do not realize anything.
My party is in favour of these amendments and would urge those opposite to recognize that there are real people out there, real men and women, who want to work. Margaret Thatcher would be delighted with the policies that this government is following, so would Ronald Reagan. However, the era of Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher is, thank goodness, now gone. We now have to move on to other things, such as creating wealth and getting people back to work.
Will the government be satisfied with 15 per cent unemployment, 20 per cent? I do not have the foggiest idea what motivates those opposite because it certainly is not their constituents.

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, for years the federal government has steadfastly refused to state categorically that Canada's fresh water is not for sale to the United States and not for sale to Mexico.
However, we now learn from the leaked North America free trade agreement, the one that was leaked to us by Ralph Nader as opposed to being presented to us by the federal government, that article 1401 states that non-energy pipelines will now be used to move products from Canada through the United States and into northern Mexico. What is a non-energy pipeline?
If a pipeline conduit is not to be used for natural gas or oil, it is likely not to be used for sewage or for wine. This is a back door, under the table, secret deal. It is an underhanded, not up front approach to provide the ways and means to transfer water from one basin into another.
To be more specific, the North America free trade agreement is enabling legislation to divert and deliver Canadian fresh water into the parched American southwest and into the desperately fresh water deficient areas of northern Mexico.
If the federal government plans to sell Canada's rivers and lakes to Mexico-

Madam Speaker, today is World Theatre Day, and I would like to take this opportunity to pay tribute to all those who have made the theatre their special form of expression and, as has been said from time immemorial, the best cure for anxiety.
I would like to mention the outstanding work being done by all stage performers and writers for the stage, by professionals, amateurs and volunteers. To overlook their contribution would have been unforgivable.

March 27, 1992
As its subject is the human condition, the theatre is a reflection of society and mankind, and its impact is felt well beyond the stage itself. Whether it moves us or makes us think, the theatre contributes to the development of society and mankind.

Madam Speaker, recently I had the opportunity to attend the 1992 Arctic Winter Games at Whitehorse in the Yukon. The games are a unique blend of sport and cultural events which bring the peoples of the north together for a week of competition and international friendship.
Athletes and artisans from Greenland, Alaska and Russia joined with Canada's representatives from the Yukon, the Northwest Territories and northern Alberta.
The games featured such sports as hockey, figure skating, and cross-country skiing along with sports that are native to the Arctic region, such as the high kick, dog sledding, and snow-shoeing.
On behalf of this House, I congratulate the 1992 Arctic Winter Games Host Society. I would also like to thank the major funding partners of the games: the city of Whitehorse, the Government of the Yukon, Sport Canada and the Yukon Lotteries Commission, along with the many other sponsors and volunteers for their efforts in making the games a very enjoyable experience for the participants and spectators.
I wish to remind members and Canadians that the next Arctic Winter Games are scheduled to be held in Slave Lake, Alberta in March of 1994.

Madam Speaker, my constituents continue to offer me thoughtful advice and comment.
Margaret Armstrong of Acton writes:
Raising two small children and trying to run a home on one income is very difficult with the current tax set-up.
Brian Holahan of Caledon writes:
Everything in this country is great, except for the excesses of government. After a shake-up, we'll be all right. The bottom line is balance the budget quickly, or you and I will go down in history as jerks.

We are taxed every way we turn. I am doubly penalized by the current tax system which allows two spouses who both work to have their incomes taxed separately while in my case, where I am the only income-earner, I cannot split my income with my spouse.

I think it is most unfortunate that people generally have lost faith in politicians. To a large extent, I think the media is to blame. The press seems to have set itself up as the official opposition.

the consensus of the Belanger-Campeau report, calling it the end of Canada.

Madam Speaker, the Saguenay-Lac-Saint-Jean region is separated from the greater Quebec area by the natural barrier of the Parc des Laurentides, also called the killer road. It is imperative to make this road safe for the well-being of our region at every level, economic, social, cultural and indeed at the family level, for all the people from the Saguenay and Lac-Saint-Jean area who are now living in Quebec City, in Montreal and elsewhere.
Given the structural problems confronting our region's economy, there is a need to focus our economic development on small and medium-sized export businesses which will have to use this antediluvian road. Statistics show that people from everywhere are afraid to venture on such a goat path, as it was referred to by a former premier of Quebec. I think that arrangements could be made with the Quebec government to meet a growing need of our region.
In closing, Madam Speaker, dare I say that, for our region 300,000 strong to have a stronger sense of our Quebec and Canadian identity means among other things extending the Trans-Canada Highway into our region.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader

Madam Speaker, the Cape Breton Development Corporation, a federally owned Crown corporation, has said no
to the request made by the Devco Pensioners Association for information pertaining to retirement packages.
The Devco Pensioners Association is being denied this information even though it is already available to management and some senior employees. The Pensioners Association has been advised that if it requires this information it should seek legal counsel and go to court.
I call upon the minister responsible for this Crown corporation to instruct its senior representatives to release this information to this association. This kind of behaviour on the part of a federally owned Crown corporation is unacceptable.
The workers have a right to know what is going on. This attempt to hide information only serves to enhance suspicion as to how this corporation is being run and how certain employees are being given preferential treatment.
Once again, I urge the minister responsible for this Crown corporation to instruct those officials with Devco to release this information to the Pensioners Association and demonstrate a little honesty.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, as you know, service clubs throughout all of Canada make a tremendous contribution to the quality of life in each of our communities. They have earned our collective thanks for that.
In addition to the many good works which all of them perform on a regular ongoing basis, one group in particular, the Kinsmen and Kinettes of Canada, have launched a national unity campaign which is particularly worthy of mention.
Since the beginning of January the Kin family's "Proud to be Canadian" tour has been travelling across Canada, having commenced virtually simultaneously on the east and west coasts. They are providing Canadians everywhere, particularly our youth, with the opportunity to sign specially designed Canadian flags as a show of hope and love for the country.
I applaud Kinsmen and Kinettes for reminding us that we as Canadians have every reason to be proud of our achievements in this our 125th anniversary.

March 27, 1992
I applaud them as well for encouraging us to join together as we will do in early May in Brandon-Souris, to express our appreciation for the privileges that a united Canada has provided, the privileges which we all too often take for granted.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext: Madam Speaker, if a government raised taxes, cut medicare programs and did not create any new jobs in its budget, what colour would its political stripes be?
Tory blue.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
No, my colleagues. I have just described a neo-Conservative NDP government of British Columbia. Provincial New Democrats behave like Liberals when in opposition, but in government those chameleons turn Tory blue.
The federal Tories brought us the GST. The provincial New Democrats in Ontario and B.C. have given us the GSP, the go south policy. Our NDP comrades are increasing the burden on business and creating an economic climate which is driving jobs south of the border.
Those silk-stocking brothers and sisters of Queen's Park and Victoria should know that Canada is losing
1,000	jobs a day. But they do not care. They are interested in propagating the socialist dogma, not helping people. Locally it will not last. Soon Premiers Wilson and McLeod will join Prime Minister Chretien thereby providing good government for Canadians.

Madam Speaker, my concern today is about the letter from the premier of Ontario that the Minister for International Trade released a couple of days ago regarding the free trade deal with Mexico. I think that was an improper thing to do. It was a breach of confidentiality.
What really concerns me is with the national unity debate coming up, it seems to me that this adds to the
tension between governments. It is not a helpful thing to do in terms of national unity in this country.
At this particular time we need confidence between the premiers and the Prime Minister. We do not need a breach of trust. We need to build up a relationship that is positive and where there is confidence among all the parties in this country.
I think the appropriate thing for the Minister for International Trade to do would be to apologize to the premier of Ontario. I think that would go a long way toward rebuilding trust in this country and helping solve the tensions that plague us in terms of national unity.

Madam Speaker, March is being proclaimed as Help Fight Liver Disease Month by the Canadian Liver Foundation. There are over 100 known liver diseases. Some of these diseases are genetic, others are environment or lifestyle related.
Currently two million Canadians suffer from some form of liver disease. Under its mandate to reduce the incidents and impact of all liver diseases, the foundation provides support for research and education.
During this month, thousands of volunteers of the Canadian Liver Foundation will be staffing booths in shopping malls and public places across the country to provide information on liver diseases and to enlist the support of the public in its effort to provide programs for patients and their families.
On behalf of the members of this House, I wish to commend the many volunteers of the Canadian Liver Foundation and encourage all Canadians to support the programs and services of the Canadian Liver Foundation.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, a recent study by Statistics Canada shows that the number of food bank users has increased by 69 per cent in Quebec between the spring of 1989 and the fall of 1990. The poverty that appears to exist in the province is even more striking in the city of Montreal.
March 27, 1992

Food banks in Montreal alone give out 12 tonnes of food each day, enough to fill the Olympic Stadium field eight feet high ten times a year. That is absolutely outrageous. Government must spare no effort to put an end to such an atrocity. The Government remains idle while Montreal is growing poorer by the day. The Tories are letting one of this country's major cities become destitute.

Madam Speaker, yesterday was a great day for our wartime merchant mariners. They learned that very soon they will be known as merchant navy veterans. Three little words, but they mean a lot. They mean that our wartime high-seas mariners will have access to the same package of programs and benefits as members of the wartime Armed Forces.
As a member of the House Standing Committee on National Defence and Veterans Affairs, I congratulate the Minister of Veterans Affairs for reacting so positively to our recommendations. The committee had heard how merchant seamen felt their contribution to the allied victory had not been properly appreciated. We learned of their long battle to be given the same status as members of the army, the navy and the air force.
Thankfully, we have a Minister of Veterans Affairs open-minded enough to examine anew the role of the merchant navy, to sift out the myths and preconceptions and to conclude that our merchant mariners deserve access to every part of the finest veterans programs in the world.
I join the minister in saying to Canada's merchant navy veterans, welcome aboard.

speakeroldname: Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George -Bulkley Valley):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, this Sunday, eight trawlers and hundreds of Canadian fishermen are heading out to the Grand Banks for a peaceful protest against foreign overfishing. These fishermen, primarily from Newfoundland, are telling Canada and the world that we must manage our fishing resource properly and that the Canadian government should assume jurisdiction over this area.
Our leader, the member for Yukon, is in Newfoundland today to meet with fishermen and to hear from them firsthand about their concerns.
Our support goes out to these courageous fishermen who are defending their jobs and Canada's fishery. Our support is with them and we look forward to their safe return.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, today's The Toronto Star reports that Ontario Premier Bob Rae went to, where else, Buffalo, New York to make a speech. One wonders if it was to receive a Man of the Year award from Buffalo City Council. He has done more to assist municipal renewal in that city than anyone since the Prime Minister brought in the GST.
The combination of the goods and services tax and NDP policies have driven millions of Canadians across the border to shop, work and carry on business.

The Minister of Finance of course says exactly the same thing. Canadians must wonder which is the lesser of these two evils.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, several months prior to the handing down of the budget in this House, our Minister of Finance engaged in a very wide-ranging discussion with business people and other Canadians to see what they wanted in our budget.
Evidently the Minister of Finance in British Columbia did not do that. The Minister of Finance here got one message from across Canada. That is there is only one taxpayer. In addition to that, that taxpayer is paying too much. In order to help the taxpayer, the federal government had to cut taxes and had to cut operating costs. Because of the program of restraint in this government,

March 27, 1992
Oral Questions
the average cost of operations has decreased 2.2 per cent since 1984.
The budget handed down yesterday in British Columbia increased the government operating costs in that province by 6.8 per cent, about three times the cost of inflation.
The federal government cut taxes. The British Columbia government increased taxes. It is now 9.2 per cent more.

Madam Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Justice.
Yesterday, the Canadian Human Rights Commission issued a real indictment of this government's record on equality. Women, children, seniors, aboriginals, people with disabilities, visible minorities, gays and lesbians, all were the victims of ongoing discrimination by this government.
What specific measures does the Minister of Justice intend to take to address the outrageous discrimination outlined in the Canadian Human Rights Commission report?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I think that the hon. member mistakes the tone and the content of the report of the Canadian Human Rights Commission. The Canadian Human Rights Commission in its annual report is always concerned to point out where we might better our record.
It is true that relative to other countries of the world, Canada has an enviable and very respected record in the area of human rights. I do not think Question Period is the appropriate place to list in great detail all of our initiatives simply because it would take too long.
I would indicate, for example, in the area of gender equality in terms of the subject matters which are in my own purview, dramatic efforts have been made to expand the responsiveness of the law, particularly the criminal justice system to the reality of Canadian women. I have
been involved in appointing a record number of women to the bench. I have appointed more women to the bench than any other Minister of Justice in this country's history and have been very pleased to do so and will continue to do so.
In addition, the very first national conference of its kind on women, law and the administration of justice was held in June 1991 in Vancouver, which for the first time brought together key decision makers and policy makers in this country, senior members of the judiciary and representatives of over 60 national organizations who promote the equal participation of women.
I could go on and on. This is not the proper context in which we should do that. The government has a very fine record in this area.

Madam Speaker, I would like to zero in on a specific area the minister should be familiar with.
Six and a half years ago, an all-party committee of this House recommended that sexual orientation be included as a prohibited ground of discrimination. The minister is quoted yesterday as saying that her department would get around to the issue as soon as it had time. "It is not for lack of people working flat out. It is a very controversial issue". Sue and a half years later, 15 years after the first inclusion in a human rights act in Canada, why is the minister putting politics ahead of principle of this very important issue?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, obtaining principle results takes time in the process of government. Since the Equality for All report, the Government of Canada has taken the position in the courts of this land that sexual orientation, for example, is an analogous ground under section 15 of the charter. That is the position we have taken in the courts.
It was in fact the wish of the various groups seeking changes in the Canadian Human Rights Act that amendments to the Canadian Human Rights Act be considered as a comprehensive package. That was a decision and approach taken by my predecessors in responding to the Equality for All report and equality initiatives in 1986. That has unfortunately made it more difficult to move the dossier ahead simply because we are dealing with a variety of issues.
March 27, 1992

I met recently in Ottawa with representatives of the various equality-seeking groups who would like to see changes in the Canadian Eluman Rights Act. I indicated that I had hoped to bring forward changes by the end of the last calendar year and simply the burden of work in my department made it impossible to do that.
The gun control legislation took longer than we expected and there simply was not enough staff time. We are now working full out on that particular file and I hope to be able to bring forward some positive things that I hope will delight the hon. member by the time we rise for the summer.

Madam Speaker, 15 years ago, the Quebec Government was the first in Canada to acknowledge that people should not suffer discrimination because of their sexual preferences. Today, 15 years later, the minister says in the House that the government is still working on it.
Why did she not endorse the policy established by a unanimous committee of this House six and a half years ago? Madam Speaker, why does the Minister of Justice continue to discriminate directly against people whose sexual preferences do not coincide with those of the majority?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext: Madam Speaker, there is no need for the government to respond to this report today. Six years ago, the government clearly announced its intentions in its response to the parliamentary committee's report. I am now working on those intentions to flesh them out, and I hope that before the summer recess I will be able to table the government's statutory response in the House.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Justice who under the federal jurisdiction has major responsibilities to protect minorities across this country.
The Canadian Human Rights Commissioner says in his report that the Government of Canada has failed in its job practices to hire and promote women, aboriginals, people with disabilities, and visible minorities fairly.
Oral Questions
I want to ask the Minister of Justice what the government is going to do to correct its dismal record as it protects human rights in this country.

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the hon. member is referring to the hiring practices of the Government of Canada. I think he is well aware that this government has certainly a record better than that of the government by the party of which he is a member in expanding employment in the Public Service to members of a variety of groups previously discriminated against.
There is a committee of the House of Commons which is in fact reviewing the Employment Equity Act and will be reporting by May 1 of this year. I think a more appropriate response will be able to be given when that parliamentary committee presents its report on its review of the Employment Equity Act as it affects the government.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, my supplementary is for the same minister.
The Minister of Justice should talk to the Minister of Finance. She will find out that the Government of Canada on the one hand has rolled back pay equity for women in the Public Service, while on the other hand its own appointed commissioner has said clearly and unequivocally that this undermines the progress as it relates to women.
I want to ask the Minister of Justice, who has an awesome responsibility in federal jurisdiction, when she will stand up for the women of this country, put some teeth into the Human Rights Act and implement programs in order to assist those Canadians.

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I have been standing up for Canadian women as long as I have been in public life, which is a very long time and significantly predates my arrival in this House.
The legislation with respect to sexual assault, for example, I think is probably the first legislation under the Criminal Code in this country that attempts to reflect adequately the reality of life as it is lived by Canadian women. The Government of Canada has not

March 27, 1992
Oral Questions
rolled back the commitment to pay equity. On the contrary, we are the only government in this country that not only accepted pay equity but made retroactive payments in pay equity. There is a dispute now between the Government of Canada and the union on the basis on which that payment should be made.
The Minister of Finance indicated in his budget that when a decision comes down in 1993, retroactive payments made under that decision, if the government should lose the argument, will be made only until 1990. The Government of Canada continues to make extraordinary payments to meet pay equity requirements of over $80 million a year. We made retroactive payments of $317 million a year at a time of severe fiscal restraint. We indicated then, with our financial priorities, the priorities we attached to this at a time when there was extraordinary pressure on the government. Fiscally the government of Canada made those retroactive payments and committed itself to pay equity.
That is the truth of the situation. We are the only government in Canada that has made that financial commitment.

Madam Speaker, my question is directed to the Acting Prime Minister. Yesterday we learned that the Montreal Board of Trade released a major economic report, reflecting the views of over 100 leading business representatives from Canada and abroad, which indicated that Canada has lost 400,000 manufacturing and industry jobs since the free trade agreement came into effect. Specifically, they identified the reasons as the high dollar policy of the government, the free trade agreement and the contradictory policies of this government.
Will the Acting Prime Minister take responsibility for what the board of trade identifies as a reason for the industrialization of our country and take some action by bringing down the high dollar value, cancelling the free trade agreement and abandoning this ridiculous pursuit of a North American free trade agreement?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
The short answer is no, Madam Speaker, we will not of course cancel the free trade agreement. As a matter of fact there are many, many success stories regarding the free trade agreement, including in my own riding. Perhaps the hon. member would like to come to Brampton some time and visit some of the companies that have done very well because of the free trade agreement. In fact, they say to me that if we did not have the free trade agreement, it would have been a lot rougher getting through the recessionary period we have just gone through.
Everybody looks for a scapegoat when we go through a difficult period of time. The Montreal Board of Trade is no different. I believe that now is the time we have to work on training, retraining, restructuring and that we have to bring Canada into the position where it will be competitive in winding up this decade and heading into the 21st century. That is what this government is doing in co-operation, I might say, with the provinces. That was one of the major subjects discussed at the First Ministers' Conference.

Madam Speaker, the hon. minister can say anything he likes, but 100 leading business voices have indicated that one of the major policies this government has introduced that is causing this de-industrialization is the free trade agreement with the United States. It is unfortunate that we have to rely on Ralph Nader for the representatives of the people of Canada to understand what the 500 pages of the NAFTA are all about.
I want to ask my hon. friend the following question. The government knows it has absolutely no mandate from the people of Canada to sign into the North American free trade agreement with the United States and Mexico, absolutely no mandate at all. Will he do the right thing and say that the government will not commit the country to this agreement before it has the support of the people of Canada to do so?

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I think the hon. member knows that there has been a great deal of consultation on the NAFTA situation. The SAGTtk have been meeting. The ITACs have been meeting. There has obviously been
March 27, 1992

considerable consultation with the provinces, with the [Translation] public service of the provinces and we will continue with
that consultation.	AVIATION SAFETY

speakeroldname: Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George-Bulkley Valley):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, when the Bush administration signed a preliminary tariff on Canadian softwood imports, Canadian lumber reloaders learned that the tariff does not just apply to the wood, it also applies to transportation, handling and any further changes to the lumber before it leaves the country.
I have received a letter and have discussed the situation with a company from Fort Erie, Ontario, Barrick Distribution Limited. I quote from the letter: "Our company is now very reluctantly looking to relocate in New York State immediately. We will have to hire American workers and lay off our Canadian employees". This company is an innocent victim of the tariff and more closures are expected across the country.
What action is the government going to take so that these kinds of operations will be protected and we will not be sold out again by this government under the free trade deal and NAFTA?

Madam Speaker, as I told my hon. friend in the House before, we have naturally protested not just this aspect of the latest imposition of a countervail duty which adds an additional burden to value-added manufacturers, but also includes the freight component of some of the products that are being shipped.
That is why we have unleashed a very strong response to this action. We have mounting support from the consumers in the United States. We have a preliminary determination. There are two more steps in this particular process, after which it will be appealed under section 19 of the free trade agreement, at which point we will of course be vindicated.

Madam Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of Transport.
Yesterday, the Deputy Prime Minister said outside the House that he was satisfied that all the legal aspects of aviation safety were in place before deregulation.
In his report on the crash at Dryden which was tabled yesterday, Justice Moshansky said that this kind of argument was unacceptable. Does the government agree with Justice Moshansky that the government has an obligation to Canadian passengers to ensure their safety, well beyond the basic legal requirements?

Madam Speaker, before answering the question, perhaps I may express, on behalf of the government, my heartfelt sympathy with the survivors and families of the victims of the terrible accident that occurred on March 10, 1989, and I do so at a time when we are again debating a subject, which must bring back some very sad memories.
It's about time.
A little late in the day.

I see the Bloc Quebecois is more interested in shouting insults across the floor, but I don't think this is the right time.
As far as the question is concerned, I may remind the hon. member that in its preliminary report, the Royal Commission on National Passenger Transportation said more than a year ago, and I quote:

"The federal government introduced in 1985 sweeping changes to the Aeronautics Act designed to give Canadian aviation its most progressive safety legislation in more than 60 years and to implement the major recommendations of the inquiry into aviation safety headed by Justice Charles Dubin".

Madam Speaker, that response is absolutely appalling. What is unacceptable is the idea that the government would hide behind the tragedy and not respond to serious, important questions about the safety of Canadian air travellers.

March 27, 1992
Oral Questions
The Dryden air crash report recommended that when the transport department identifies a shortage of resources to ensure safety, this information should be communicated up the line to the minister. In its response, the government says: "A policy will be developed".
Is this not an admission that successive ministers of transport have failed in their responsibility to obtain the information that they require to ensure Canadian passenger safety?

Madam Speaker, yesterday I mentioned the fact that as soon as the Moshansky commission's report was tabled, the government tabled its response to the 191 recommendations.
I also mentioned that to deal with these 191 recommendations, we had set up an implementation team consisting of 20 members recruited from the Department of Transport and from the industry, including the associations, employers, and employees. I made a commitment that six months from now we would table a public report on the work done by the team during that time.

Madam Speaker, in 1989 a leaked memo from the chief of operations and certification of inspectors at Transport Canada noted, and I will quote from that memo: "Air carrier inspection is no longer capable of meeting even minimum requirements". Transport Canada warned the minister in 1989. Justice Moshansky warned the minister again yesterday.
When will the minister provide the required number of commercial jet aircraft inspectors to ensure safety in the skies?

Madam Speaker, yesterday I provided all the statistics, and these show that we have the number of inspectors required. I would like to refer the hon. member to the 1989 annual report of the Canadian Aviation Safety Board which says this: "The above statistics indicate that the 1980s was a decade of significant improvement in Canadian aviation safety." In its 1990 report, the board said that accident statistics for aircraft licensed in Canada were a clear
indication that the last decade was marked by a significant improvement in aviation safety in Canada.
Madam Speaker, I believe that throughout that time, the Department of Transport continued to give aviation safety the priority it deserves.

Madam Speaker, the minister's rhetoric gives us the government position and makes it quite clear that it will continue to put at risk the lives of the air travelling public in this country to save a buck. That is what he is saying.
Just yesterday the director of air carrier standards and operations at Transport Canada confirmed that according to his own department's figures, at least 10 more inspectors are needed immediately for commercial air carrier inspections. Will the minister immediately hire 10 additional commercial jet aircraft inspectors? Yes or no?

Madam Speaker, it was interesting to hear what the chairman of the Moshansky commission, Mr. Justice Moshansky, said this morning in an interview on Canada AM. When asked whether it was safe to fly in Canada, he said: "Yes, I think it is safe to fly in Canada. I think we have one of the safest transportation systems in the world. That is not to say it is perfect. The thrust of my report was to identify deficiencies which should be corrected in order to bring it closer to perfection".

Madam Speaker, yesterday Justice Moshansky brought down a report dealing with the commercial aviation industry. I emphasize commercial aviation industry. Also yesterday, in defence of the government's record on safety the minister said: "In 1981 there were 700 aircraft accidents in Canada. In 1991 there were 449 accidents".
What the minister failed to tell this House and Canadians is that when it comes to commercial aviation in this country, according to the Canadian Aviation Safety Board reports, there has been an increase of 34 per cent in the number of accidents between 1984, the year that this government came to power, and 1991.
I ask the minister to explain why he chose to give statistics dealing with the broad base of the aviation industry, including the general aviation sector and the government sector, as opposed to the real stats which deal with commercial aviation which was what the Moshansky report was all about. speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I move that the 23rd report of the Standing Committee on House Management, presented to the House on Friday, February 14, 1992, be concurred in.
It certainly is a pleasure for me to present and speak to this particular committee report. It has been an honour to take part in the debate and discussions relating to the experimental guidelines governing the broadcasting of committee meetings. That was a result of Standing Order 119.1(2).
I just want to quote a few things from the report because I think they are very important for all members here and certainly for the public.
On the one hand, there is the desire for openness of democratic political institutions and freedom of the press.
We can all understand and recognize that.
On the other hand, there are serious concerns of parliamentary privilege and the effects of broadcasting on parliamentary institutions.
There are many strong arguments in favour of the broadcasting of committee proceedings. A great deal of important work is done by members in committees and the public should have an opportunity to see this-The broadcasting of the proceedings of committees would provide a more balanced view of the parliamentary process and would enhance the public's perception and appreciation of the work of Parliament and parliamentarians.
The risk is that the collegiality of committees could be destroyed and replaced by a more partisan and adversarial approach by all parties.
That is something we do not want to happen.
The public has a right to know what is going on in Parliament but it is important to remember that it is a legislative body rather than a television program.
The committee's task was to establish guidelines for broadcasting that would preserve the collegial and informal atmosphere of committee meetings, thus providing a more balanced view of the parliamentary process.
We studied a couple of reports that have been very important and very instrumental in bringing this final report together. Watching the House at Work, the Cook report, provided a lot of background information and impetus to this report.
The other one was The Role and Importance of Committees, the 1985 report of the McGrath committee because that certainly changed the role of committees. It changed the importance of committees in my view. We have taken those two reports, combined them with the views, the information we heard from many, many witnesses.
Of particular importance was the information we received in the provincial legislatures of Ontario and Quebec. They took us through their process and helped us with it. We understood it and certainly, it allowed us to make decisions. In some cases it changed our views and opinions of the particular process.
It was necessary to distinguish two aspects of broadcasting. First, there is recording whereby we have gavel to gavel coverage of the committee meeting. Second, there is reporting, that is, allowing the electronic media access to committee meetings to coverage of the proceedings for recording purposes.
The committee, in its wisdom, decided upon a phasing-in approach to broadcasting, first to allow the media to record the sound or audio feed of all public committee meetings. The technology for this is already in place. This can be used by print and radio journalists very easily and television journalists could use it together with a picture of the person speaking.
We would also like to see the audio of all committee proceedings broadcast, either through OASIS or by closed-circuit FM radio. This would enable members and their staff and the media to monitor committee meetings.
Two problems presented themselves with the next phase of broadcasting. We wanted to make sure that the House was going to have the responsibility of recording and distributing tape proceedings, but those costs would be astronomical. In addition, there are just too many committee meetings to have all of them broadcast on the parliamentary channel.
The committee recommends one committee room would be set up on a non-permanent basis using existing or rented equipment at a minimum cost. The proceedings would be recorded gavel to gavel and broadcast live on OASIS and on a delayed basis on the parliamentary channel.
March 27, 1992

The recording of proceedings would be undertaken by or on behalf of the House and under direct control and supervision of the House personnel.
Given the multitude of committee meetings per day, a decision-making process must be put in place to determine which committee will be broadcast. We believe the decision should be made by the House leaders and if the House leaders are unable to agree the matter could be referred to the management committee.
We expect that a system will be devised whereby the committees and their chairmen will indicate their desire to have particular proceedings broadcast. The House leaders, of course, would take that into account, as well as public interest and fairness and reflecting the views of the different members.
We believe the issue of broadcasting committees will need to be reviewed after six months, as well as having a system set up to review complaints.
That is the essence of the report. I would just like to make one final comment if I may, and that is concerning the co-operation of the members on the committee. I want to particularly comment to the members from Saint-Leonard, Kingston and the Islands and particularly the member from Saint-Denis, who is here but is not listening to me at the present time.
